result.markdown:
--- title: "Lesson 6: Graphing 2/2" toc: true fig-align: center fig-width: 8 fig-height: 3.5 code-copy: true code-overflow: wrap code-line-numbers: true code-fold: true code-tools: true eval: true message: false warning: false # toc: true --- ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code code-fold="false" code-summary="Data use in graphs below"} library(tidyverse) dat <- read_csv("https://raw.githubusercontent.com/BrighamEaquinto/brighameaquinto.github.io/master/datasets/insurance.csv") ``` ::: ## Labeling #### `labs()` **Explanation** The `labs()` function is used to add label to the plot like the x-axis, the y-axis, and title. **Options**: - title - subtitle - caption - x - y **Example** ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} ggplot(dat, aes(x = region, fill = sex))+ geom_bar()+ labs(title = "Counts of Regions", x = "Regions", y = "Amount", fill = "Sex")+ theme_bw() ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](lesson6_ggplot_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-2-1.png){width=768} ::: ::: ## Faceting ### `facet_wrap()` & `facet_grid()` This of faceting as a third variable. - `facet_wrap()` ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](lesson6_ggplot_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-3-1.png){width=768} ::: ::: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code code-fold="true" code-summary="Code"} ggplot(dat, aes(x = region, fill = sex))+ geom_bar()+ facet_wrap(~sex)+ labs(title = "Faceted Graph", x = "", y = "Amount", fill = "Sex")+ theme( title = element_text(size = 20), axis.title = element_text(size = 10), legend.title = element_text(size = 10), legend.position = "none") ``` ::: ## Themes The following theme options affect all the non-data aspects - `+ theme_bw()` - `+ theme_linedraw()` - `+ theme_light()` - `+ theme_dark()` - `+ theme_minimal()` - `+ theme_classic()` - `+ theme_void()` - `+ theme_test()` ## Coloring #### Aesthetic It is possible to set colors dynamically based on column or to set it as a static color. Setting colors dynamically and statically. ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](lesson6_ggplot_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-5-1.png){width=768} ::: ::: ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](lesson6_ggplot_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-6-1.png){width=768} ::: ::: :::{.callout-tip collapse="true"} ## Further Reading #### Fill vs. Color `fill = 'orange'` `color` left as default ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](lesson6_ggplot_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-7-1.png){width=768} ::: :::
`fill` left as default `color = 'black'` ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](lesson6_ggplot_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-8-1.png){width=768} ::: :::
`fill = 'orange'` `color = 'black'` ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](lesson6_ggplot_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-9-1.png){width=768} ::: :::
You can do a combination of inside and outside. `fill = 'orange'` inside aesthetic `color = Species` outside aesthetic. Notice this is a column in the dataset, not a static color. ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](lesson6_ggplot_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-10-1.png){width=768} ::: ::: :::
